overview.title: What this blend is
overview.text: CagriSema pairs a GLP-1 agonist (semaglutide) with a long-acting amylin analog (cagrilintide) to address appetite through two independent neurological pathways. Where semaglutide acts on GLP-1 receptors in the hypothalamus and brain stem, cagrilintide activates amylin receptors in a different brain region. Phase 3 REDEFINE trials have demonstrated superior weight loss compared to semaglutide alone — this is the clinical rationale for the combination.

use_cases.title: Use cases (real-world)
use_cases.text: Use cases are framed as intent + context, not as a recommendation.
People usually consider blends when they’re trying to simplify decision-making, stack fewer vials, or chase a combined effect profile. The downside is more moving parts and more uncertainty.
If one component would be a bad fit for you (meds, history, side effects), the blend is also a bad fit — even if the other component seems appealing.

interaction_summary.title: Interaction summary
interaction_summary.text: Interaction flags are category prompts — not dosing instructions.
Blends inherit interaction risk from every component. If one component has a meaningful interaction class, treat the blend as having that interaction class.
If you’re on prescription meds (especially cardio, anticoagulant/antiplatelet, serotonergic, immunomodulating), treat uncertainty as a reason to slow down and verify with a clinician.

blend.rationale: CagriSema pairs a GLP-1 agonist (semaglutide) with a long-acting amylin analog (cagrilintide) to address appetite through two independent neurological pathways. Where semaglutide acts on GLP-1 receptors in the hypothalamus and brain stem, cagrilintide activates amylin receptors in a different brain region. Phase 3 REDEFINE trials have demonstrated superior weight loss compared to semaglutide alone — this is the clinical rationale for the combination.
blend.synergy_note: GLP-1 and amylin receptor signaling produce satiety through distinct circuits that don't overlap. Combining them generates greater appetite suppression than either alone without requiring higher GLP-1 doses — which is significant because most of semaglutide's GI side effects are dose-dependent. The combination gets more out of a moderate GLP-1 dose.
blend.who_its_for: Weight loss, particularly where single-agent GLP-1 therapy has reached a plateau or where GI tolerance limits further dose escalation.

component_roles.cagrilintide: Long-acting amylin analog — satiety signaling via brain stem and hypothalamic amylin receptors; independent of GLP-1 pathway
component_roles.semaglutide: GLP-1 receptor agonist — appetite suppression, gastric emptying, blood sugar regulation via GLP-1 pathway
